Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2010 07:14AM boatergrl wrote: I can relate to this topic becuase I was three weeks out from my mx when I met with the onco who asked me at that point if I wanted to do the oncotype test.  My BS had told me to ask the onco about it but it never occured to me that the test had not been ordered.  So here I am, three weeks out from surgery and now waiting for the onco test to come back.  I can't understand why the BS didn't order it. If I had known I would have insisted he do it or ask the onco to order it before my appointment.  Without the info I feel like the appointment with the onco was a waste of time and now I am dealing with another 2 weeks of anxious waiting.
Posts.Title: I am so frustrated: Who is supposed to order the oncotyping? surfette kira1234

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 04:19PM boatergrl wrote: thanks for the tips. Yesterday I was feeling some of the sensations you mentioned- kind of wierd but ok. I called the dr today he said the burning was due to the drain. I think I'm a bad patient - I hate sitting around and am probably trying to push too much.  It's just that when I sit around I start to feel anxious and down, but my limited ability to move isn't helping my mood either.  Does anyone have any suggestions on sleeping.  I've been on the couch because I can't get out of bed and pretty much have to sleep sitting up.  You all sound so upbeat it's great and really helpful - it's a good reminder that I won't be in this stage of the game forever.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 06:05PM boatergrl wrote: it's really an intense burning sensation always in the same spot, just under my breast.  I'm so glad to hear that you are doing better. I had a friend who had similar problems to yours and to be honest her war story kind of scared me  - which is why I'm now so paranoid about infection and fever. I actually thought about not doing reconstruction at the time of my surgery because of her experience but told myself she was just a fluke.  What do you all do to keep your mind busy - clearly I'm obsessing and worrying too much.

How's life in Costa Mesa?  My brother lived there for years and I have good friends there too.

My onco has never done a PET on me and one of my friends is adamant that this is malpractice. She insists that it's standard to do a PET on a regular basis.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 10:46PM boatergrl wrote: Unfortunately her sister, who had been diagnosed as stage 0 DCIS developed tumors in her brain. Her doctor couldn't explain how that happened given how early they had caught it. It has us all a bit freaked out. My friend is thinking that if they had done a PET earlier they might have been more successful. And she is very insistent that I get a PET.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 12:52PM boatergrl wrote: OK, I need a new OC. I mentioned before that he came highly recommended, but I think he's too busy. It's not uncommon for him to forget to order tests or give me results but they have been relatively minor tests such as a vitamin D level. Saw him today and asked the lab tech specifically what tests were being done and it turned out he ordered the cancer marker test for ovarian cancer not breast cancer. The lab tech laughed and said good thing you caught that! I just don't have confidence in him and want to feel like I can trust him with my life-literally. I'm going to have to go outside my area and would love suggestions as to how to find a good dr with a good reputation. Since I won't know anybody I don't want to shoot in the dark.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 10:04AM boatergrl wrote: HI everyone - I am new to your group, just found you yesterday.  I met with my onco yesterday for the first time and my head is swimming.  I thought he would tell me flat out you need chemo or you don't but what I got was a bunch of stats, a list of side effects and told to think about it.  It seems like from what he said my risk of reoccurance is the same if I do tamoxofin or chemo and that there is no added benefit from doing both. I then called someone I know who is a radiology onco who told me the same thing and said that chemo is not going to have any greater effect on my odds. He seemed to advise not to do it becuase of the short and more importantly long term SE.  I am overwhelmed and want to make the right decision.  I don't want someone to tell me 2 years from now that I've got a brain tumor because I didn't make the right treatment choice.  Any advise or suggestions?
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 11:18AM boatergrl wrote: riancity - did you have the onco type test?  If so did that effect your decision to do the chemo? I'm going crazy today - the waiting and wondering is awful!  I am feeling like this will always be the primary thing in my thought process and I can't shut it off!  I really miss my old life where my days were consumed with other thoughts/concerns.
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2010 10:46AM boatergrl wrote: Leigh - I can completely relate to your emotional frustration.  I am also a person who gets back in the game quickly and pushes to get myself back in control of things.  I was totally unprepared for the physical and emotional ride I have been on.  It's not quite been 2 weeks since my surgery and I can see that I am making steady progress, but have times of total exhaustion, blues and anxiety.  The women in this group are fantastic!  The knowledge and support here is priceless.  As others have said, the pain meds and anesthesia do a number on us and take time to work out of our bodies.  Plus, the stress we have been under pre and post surgery not only effects our emotions but our bodies as well.  We have all experienced a physical and emotion trauma and like all trauma experiences it takes time for us to heal.  It might be hard for you to give into the need to rest, but try to if you can.  You will probably find you'll have days with lots of energy and then days of being worn out.
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2010 10:03PM boatergrl wrote: raincity - a couple of weeks ago you mentioned that you were going to talk to your onco about staying with chemo or not.  I know I'm prying, but did you have that converstation and if so how did it go? to all:  I am still waiting for my onco test results.  At my first meeting with the onco he told me that my rate of recurrence is the same if I do chemo or just tamox.  Today I heard through the nurse that "becuase I'm so young" he is leaning towards chemo.  She said it was the idea of throwing everything at it as possible because "we like to keep our patients around as long as possible".  I haven't talked to the doctor again and as I said I don't have the onco test results.  I feel lost and overwhelmed again. Any advice out there?  Should we just hang tight till the onco results and go with whatever that says?  Should I get a second opinion? Am I missing something?

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 08:14PM boatergrl wrote: you all have great suggestions!  I like the idea of keeping mints and something to suck on and a wedge cushion sounds like a great idea too. Laying down in bed is out of the question right now, but that would probably help on the couch too.  I'm very fortunate to have a very supportive husband but his work demands right now are really high so my mom moved in for a while to help out.  Lot's of family and friends have been bringing food over, but nothing really appeals to me so I told my mom today to stock up on some ice cream.  Fortunately and unfortunately, my 5 year old daugther is home with strep so we have been working on some craft projects which has been a good distraction.  I've also gotten suggestions about probiotics, but read about a study this summer that suggested that if you have a weak immune system probotics could allow bad bacteria to travel to areas of weakness in the body.  so I'm kind of up in the air about it. I'm interested in the discussion about taking blood pressure readings in an arm where nodes where taken out.  At the hospital I had to wear a special band on my left arm so no one would take a pressure there.  Is this a permanent thing or does it resolve?  I had three nodes taken out - all came back clear but my doctor didn't give me any warning about this issue.

My second question is about the expanders.  Mine is pretty uncomfortable all the time.  Is this normal?  Will it ever feel like a part of me or will I always be aware of this thing stuck under my chest wall?

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2010 08:55PM boatergrl wrote: raincitygirl- It's so hard to make the decision to do chemo or not - I completely understand where you were coming from when you made your decision and I completely understand where you are now with it.  I can see myself caught up so much in the fear and the emotion and trying to grab at anything that will put my life back together - in a way that I never have to go through this again.  Right now I am sitting and waiting for the oncotype results and I think I am more nervous about that than at any other time during the nightmare of a roller coaster ride. But it could just be that the stress of the whole thing is just piling up right now. Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 12:55PM boatergrl wrote: Gosh, I just found you guys and wish I had found you a few weeks ago.  I had a mastectomy on my left side with expander 6 days ago.  Was scared to death going into it, as many of you have said, but was anxious to get the cancer out of my body!  I have a couple of concerns that I haven't seen posted here.  One is that I keep getting a burning sensation. It lasts only a few seconds and it seems to come when I am moving from a reclined position to sitting up, but in the past 12 hours it has happened more frequently.  Has anyone had that experience?  Also, I read in one of the posts that they were told to swab the drain with alcohol.  We weren't told to do that and I'm worried about infection.  The drain is pretty uncomfortable and I can't wait to get it out!  I was surprised at how wiped out I felt after the surgery.  It really took several days to get some energy back.  But, hopefully things will just get better each day.
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 05:51PM boatergrl wrote: Eileen, you seem to be very knowledgeable about how we can take care of our selves.  I've seen mentioned here taking vitamin D - what does that do - do you know?  Also, my appetite has been off since I started my antibiotic - any advice for that. I have to say that I was unprepared for how much this whole thing was going to kick my butt.
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2010 06:00PM boatergrl wrote: my surgery was 10/27.  I'm getting pretty good use of my arm already - but am trying to be very careful.  I am left handed and the surgery was on my left side, so I often find myself doing things without realizing it.  The pain really isn't bad- except for what I think is the drain, which is pretty uncomfortable.  When I first came home my temp was running below normal - now it seems to be right at normal or slightly higher - got up to 99 yesterday.  The doctor told me to call if it gets to 101.  Is it normal to be a little elevated?  If you all haven't guessed I am full of anxiety and infection is one of the things I'm worried about. I feel pretty blue too and have no appetite.  I just want to feel like myself again.
Posts.Title: October 2010 Mastectomy cc4npg cc4npg
